titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VII:30 Sunday. Attended Church this morning with George. Prayers for the first Sunday in Advent were read by Mr Wallington, and the Communion Service jointly with Mr Carr— The Sermon was by Mr Milman from John I.3. [“]All things were made by him; and without him was not any thing made, that was made.” It was intended for an Advent Sermon. Mr Milman said it was impossible this world should have existed from eternity, for this among many other reasons. That if it had, it must have been by this time overflowing with population, or entirely depopulated. This is a sample of his logic— After Church at the door, I spoke to Major and Mrs Morison, lately returned from Scotland— Walked an hour before dinner. John and Charles returned this Evening to School— Caroline, Laura, Charlotte and Frank Nicholas, with their friend Mr Cooke the Musician, spent the Evening with us— They played on the Piano and sung.

2. VII: The Misses Nicholas were here this Morning— I wrote to my Father— Walk to Hanwell and Ealing. It was between nine and ten in the Evening when George came home from school. Ellen Nicholas returned home this Evening, after having spent upwards of three Months with my wife— I read Brown’s Essay upon Satire, addressed to Warburton and bound up with Pope’s works: an honour which it hardly deserves. It is a poor imitation of Pope’s Style and manner; and extols him as the first of Satirists; and these were perhaps the reasons for Warburton’s admitting it into his Edition of Pope, from which it has been copied into others— I have totally ceased writing verses

3. VII:30. I received this morning a Letter from C. E. A. Schwabe, foreign Secretary to the British and Foreign School Society, requesting me by direction of the Committee to attend and assist at a General Meeting of the Society at Freemason’s Hall, on Thursday the 12th. of this Month at 12 O’Clock, the Duke of Sussex to be in the Chair— I am requested to send my answer to Mr Millar, Queen Street, Bloomsbury. Also a Letter from Grubb, mentioning the box addressed to me, arrived from St. Petersburg in the Ship Holderness and offering his services to procure it for me. I answered Grubb’s Letter, and taking Antoine with me to town sent him with it. I found at the office in Craven Street Mr John Winthrop of Boston, who gave me Letters from my father and from Dr Waterhouse; both dated in February. That from my father was only an introduction. Winthrop has been several months in Holland, and has arrived only within these few days in London— There were likewise three American Sailors, applying for relief, refused them by the Consul. I told them to call again at the Consul’s to-morrow, and wrote a Letter to Coll. Aspinwall, urging him again, under the special circumstances of the present times, to relax from the rules of refusing relief to all who come from another Consulate, or who have been in the British Service— Besides these there was a Letter from James Holmes formerly the American Consul at Newry; enclosing again his and Vice-Consul at Londonderry’s Accounts for relief furnished to destitute American Seamen sworn to, but without vouchers; and with a copy of a Letter from B. Pleasonton, of the Department of State, to Holmes’s
Correspondent at New-York, referring him to me for the settlement of his Account. A long Letter from W. H. G. Page upon Cook’s Affairs; with copies of a Correspondence between him Page and Earl Bathurst; in which Page asks for official papers, necessary for the trial of Cook’s action against Maxwell; before the Court of Law. Bathurst declines furnishing the papers, and Page writes asking me to apply for them ministerially— Then a Letter from Nathaniel Brewer, stating that he was on board an American vessel that foundered at Sea; lost all his papers, credits &c. wants money and will give a bill upon Genl. John Mason of Georgetown— He left a Letter from Mason to him, and several others, all written in 1814. and accidentally saved, as vouchers of his credit. I left word with Smith, that the man being totally unknown to me, and having severely suffered by listening to such Stories I was sorry I must refer him to the persons upon whom his credits were drawn which he had lost. As they must have as much reason as I, and probably more to credit the vouchers he produces— Antoine came back at five. It was too late for the Custom-House. He brought me a reply from Grubb, who will attend to the business to-morrow— A Letter from Aspinwall, about the restriction of Passengers to unoccupied Tonnage; and the news that Mrs Von Harten died the day before Yesterday. My time had been so much absorbed that I could not walk— Home at 7. Brought with me the Memoirs of the life of Brand-Hollis, by Dr Disney— It was sent for my perusal by Mr Aspland— In the Appendix there are several Letters from my father and mother to Hollis; which I read in the Evening— On the whole, Hollis’s character is not a very bright one.

4. VII:15. Passed a sleepless Night. Received this Morning a Letter from the Bavarian Minister, Mr Pfeffel containing enquiries about a German named Plattner who says I dissuaded him from going to America. Also a Letter from Mr Von Harten to my wife, communicating the death of Mrs Von Harten— Walk to Hanwell and Ealing. Mr W. H. G. Page was here, entertaining me an hour and a half with the cause of Mr G. Cooke which is to come on for trial in the Court of King’s Bench this week. Major Appleton whom he summoned from Guernsey is here. But Page supposes he will admit the fact of having destroyed Cook’s factory, alledge in justification that it was by orders from his superior Officer, but that he has not the orders here; or that they are confidential and he cannot produce them. Page therefore wrote to Earl Bathurst, requesting him to furnish copies of the orders issued from his Office as Secretary of State to Governor Maxwell. But Lord Bathurst has declined furnishing the copies, on the ground that the Government does not think proper to interfere with the Evidence. In point of fact Page says, the Government have made Maxwell’s cause their own. They have determined to defend him; insomuch that the Attorney General, whom Page had retained for Cook, now is with drawn, and declines taking part in the cause. It has been decided in a late Cause against the Governor of Heligoland, that the Secretaries of State are not amenable to the Court for the production of their official archives or papers of Office; and Page’s Solicitor and Counsel are apprehensive that by this suppression of the Evidence which is in the possession of this Government, but which they will not produce, Cook must become nonsuit, and having once lost hold of Maxwell, may never be able to come at him again, as he is now in the West Indies. Page therefore wished me to apply to Lord Bathurst, demanding that the Orders to Maxwell should be produced— I told him that this was a point involving the principles of internal Administration of the Country. I could not as a foreign Minister demand that a high Officer of State should produce for a Court of Justice within the Country, which he had already declined to furnish, under an established, and settled rule of Office— I must presume that the judicial Court, would be independent of Executive influence; and that an Officer, alledged Orders, for doing that which in itself was an outrage to the person and property of an individual, the Court would compel him to produce his orders. I could not conceive that the Court would nonsuit Cook for not producing papers which it was impossible for him to obtain, or that they would let an Officer who alledged orders for his justification, without producing them— I thought I could not with propriety make this demand of Lord Bathurst—that if I should make it, it would not only be refused, but the demand would probably give Offence to this Government, and might perhaps not be approved by my own. That I regretted it much, as it would have given me pleasure to have afforded any assistance in my power to the Cause of Mr Cook. Page said he was perfectly satisfied with the reasons I had given him, and hoped to avail himself of the suggestion I had given him, that the necessity of producing the orders should be put upon the other party. He said he had Gurney the short hand writer engaged to take down the trial, and he had told Mr Hamilton the Under Secretary of the State in the foreign Department
that if for the want of evidence, in the possession of His Majesty’s Ministers but which they would not suffer to be produced, Mr Cook should be obliged to become nonsuit and should lose his cause, there would be only one resource left for him— A true and faithful statement of his whole case should be printed, and a copy of it should be delivered to every member of both houses of the British Parliament, and to every member of both houses of the American Congress. And he had added that although he well knew a Nation could not go to War, for the wrongs of one individual, yet when the next war between Great-Britain and the United States, from whatever Cause should take place, and the Peace should come to be negotiated, he hoped Cook’s case would then be brought forward to be negotiated, though it might be at the distance of twenty years— After Page went away, I walked to Hanwell and Ealing; and in the Evening turned over the Remembrancer for the year 1779. where I found many reminiscences of things once interesting, but which now seem but the incoherent fragments of a dream.

5. VII:30. Mr John Winthrop came out and paid me a long visit. He is desirous of obtaining the appointment of Consul at Hamburg and wished me to write to the Secretary of State in his favour. But thinks it probable no appointment will be made until the new President comes into Office. He has no doubt that Mr Monroe will be elected, and says he has reason to believe, and it is generally understood that Mr Monroe will offer the Office of Secretary of State to me. He wishes therefore to bespeak my influence in his favour after my return to the United States which he is convinced will be next Spring— He says he was promised the Office of Navy Agent at Boston; three or four years ago: and that it was given by Paul Hamilton, then Secretary of the Navy, and through the influence of the Member of Congress Seaver, to a man named Amos Binney, who had no claim to it— I told Winthrop that I would readily write to the Secretary of State in his favour; but that I had no reason to suppose that the State Department would be offered to me, by Mr Monroe— Boyd had indeed told me that there was some talk of that kind at Washington; but I consider it all, as the mere gossiping, speculative distribution of public offices, which is always going on in the United States. Winthrop was about two hours here; and walked round the garden with me. He then returned to Brentford, to be taken up by a party with whom he had come out from London, and who were to dine at Twickenham.— I received this Morning Letters—from J. A. Smith, with notice that he has removed the Office and his lodgings from N. 13 to N: 28. Craven Street— From Coll. Aspinwall the Consul, in reply to mine of the 3d. about the Sailors— From Grubb, who has been to the Custom House, for the boxes addressed to me— That from Russia he expects to receive this day. The Portrait taken from Connell at Dover has been ordered to be sent to me at my own house— From W. Couling at Carmarthen; impatient for an answer to his proposals, from the Governor of Virginia; and distressed by disappointments in his business here.— From S. Bourne—Consul at Amsterdam—complaining, soliciting; and enclosing a Letter to the President of the United States to be forwarded— The second Post brought a Note from the Wurtemberg Minister General Neuffer; enclosing a new paper, for additional authentication. It is a Certificate from J. H. Ch. Helmuth, Minister of the German Lutheran St. Michael’s and Zion’s Congregation at Philadelphia, of an abstract from the records of that Congregation, of the burial there of a person named Bilger, one of its Members.— It is authenticated by the Mayor of Philadelphia, Robert Wharton, under the Seal of the City— General Neuffer wants an official visa upon it; but I know not precisely whose— I walked to Ealing and Gunnersbury. John and Charles dined at home; and when they returned to school, my wife and George, went with them, and spent the Evening with the young Ladies at Dr Nicholas’s— I passed it in my cabinet answering the Letters of Mr Schwabe, Mr Pfeffel the Bavarian Minister and W. Couling— I declined the invitation to attend and assist at the Meeting of the British and foreign School Society next Thursday.— For as this Society is made quite an affair of party in this Country, and as they made me an acting personage at the Meeting that I did attend last May I am by no means satisfied of the propriety of my attendance at all their Meetings— My wife & George came home between 11. and 12.

6. VIII:15. Received this Morning a Letter from Mr William Vaughan, who has removed his residence from East-hill Wandsworth to Clapham Common. I rose late this morning having balanced my loss of sleep on Tuesday Night, but an unusual portion of it last Night. This day I had nothing to divert my attention from business yet it was almost entirely wasted in idleness.— I walked towards Isleworth and through Sion House Park, the first time since we have resided here. Passed the Evening in Conversation.

7. VII:30. My wife intended to have gone to London this day; but upon receiving an answer from Mrs Delafield, concluded not to go. I walked as far as Brentford, where the Carriage overtook me. I had proposed paying some visits, but it was too late when I reached town. I stopped at Richardson’s N. 96. Pall Mall, and made some enquiries about Wines, and took samples. Went to N. 28 Craven Street; to which place Smith has removed the Office, and his lodgings— I found there the box which had arrived from Russia, in the
Ship Holderness, addressed to me. It had been brought yesterday by a Custom-House Officer, and opened by him— It contained only two Books, one a Quarto Volume elegantly bound, a Manuscript addressed to me, by F. E. Montreal, upon the external Commerce of Russia, by the Black Sea, and the Sea of Azoff. And the other La Pie’s Chart of the Mediterranean and Black Seas. There was also a Letter from Robert Aspland, with a copy of the Memoirs of Thomas Brand Hollis, by their Author Dr Disney—and a number of Mr Aspland’s own publications; chiefly upon the subject of Unitarianism— A note from T. M. Jones, sending me Mr Pillet’s Book upon England. And there were Cards from Mr Rotch, Dr Platt, P. V. Ogden and F. B. Ogden, the last of whom has lately arrived from America; and left with his Card, a Letter of Recommendation from my brother— These papers and the copies of Page’s Correspondence with Earl Bathurst, relative to Cook’s cause which I now read, engaged me till five. I left Couling’s maps, as he had requested at N. 415. Strand, and went with Smith and dined at my old Leyden acquaintance Dr Cooke’s. N. 71. Gower Street. The Company consisted of Mr Frend, Mr Burdett, Dr. Cooke the navy Chaplain, and Mr Const and Mr Cunningham, two Gentlemen whom I had not seen before— I soon found that they were not in political opinion with the rest of the Company— The political Conversation however was of a very moderate character.— A Surgeon of the Northumberland, named Warden, has just published an account of his Conversations with Napoleon at St Helena; in which he touched upon some of the heaviest charges that have been brought against him; and among the rest that of his having poisoned his sick at Jaffa— Mr Const appeared anxious to discredit the account of the matter, as told by Napoleon to Warden; and said, that Desgenettes, the Surgeon, to whom the proposal of administering the Opium to the sick was made, died in this Country— That he told Dr Bailey, who had repeated it at the table where we were sitting, that Buonaparte had proposed to him to despatch all the sick with opium—that he made no assertion that they were in a state beyond the chance of recovery— That he Desgenettes had refused; saying that his business was to heal, and not to kill; and had left him; and did not attend again at the hospital— That the sick were committed to another man; and all died; giving it to be understood that what he had refused to do, had been done by another— We had also conversation upon the riots that took place in London, last Monday—upon Jewish Sacrifices, and upon Astronomy, in which I perceive Mr Frend is an Anti Newtonian. We sat at table until past eleven— I then took Smith to his lodgings, and it was half past one in the Morning when I reached home—

8. VIII: Attended Church alone. Mr Carr, read Prayers for the second Sunday in Advent It happened that the 39th. Psalm, which is always read as a part of the funeral service was one of the Psalms of the day, and Mr Carr appeared to be much affected in reading it. Mr Milman preached the Sermon from John I.14. “And the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us”—it was a sequel of the last Sunday’s discourse— After Church I went with my wife, and paid visits to Mr and Mrs Carr; and to Mr and Mrs Copland at Gunnersbury. At Mr Carr’s they informed us that the Clitherow family had returned from Worthing. the Copland’s invited us to dine with them on Monday the 16th:— Mr Winthrop and J. A. Smith came from town and dined with us: George’s Schoolfellows Chambré and James Chichester also dined here. They all left us, about ten in the Evening.

9. VII:30. Having been shortened of exercise several days, I commenced my walk this day soon after two O’Clock, went through the village of Isleworth, crossed over Richmond Bridge, and returned along the Banks of the Thames, till I came opposite to Kew Palace where I crossed the River in a ferry boat to Brentford. It must have been a walk of about eight Miles, and absorbed so great a portion of the day that I had scarcely any left for writing— In the Evening I read the preface to Pope’s works.

10. VII:30. By this Morning’s Post I received a Letter from J. A. Smith, enclosing one from Jas. Maury at Liverpool; and three Cards from the British and foreign School Society— One a ticket for two Ladies or a Gentleman and Lady, to the Meeting at Free Mason’s Tavern next Thursday— The second a Platform ticket for myself; and the third, a Card of W. Carston and J. Foster as deputed from the Committee— They left the Cards at my Office yesterday, and Smith writes were urgent for my attendance at the Meeting. As I had however already sent a written answer declining to attend, I suppose no further answer necessary— Mr Maury mentioned having received and forwarded to me by the Mail Coach, despatches for me. Two Packets of the despatches Smith sent out— One from the State Department— A triplicate of a Letter from J. Graham with a despatch to be forwarded to L. Harris, Chargé d’Affaires at St. Petersburg— The other from the Department of War; enclosing an unsealed packet for G. Boyd containing a letter to him from Mr Crawford, the Secretary at War, directing him to purchase 2000 dollars worth of books and maps in France for the use of the Department. A subsequent
Letter, signed George Graham acting Secretary at War, directing only 1200 dollars to be expended for books and maps in France, and the rest to be applied to purchases in England with the Letters there was a list of French Military Books which they have already at the War Office— I went with my wife into London. We called and left Cards at Lord and Lady Castlereagh’s; they having just returned from Ireland— At the Office in Craven Street, I found Mr Winthrop waiting, and the rest of the despatches, forwarded by Mr Maury— That is a file of the National Intelligencer from 1. to 15. October which Smith had opened— Also a packet which had been brought to the Office by Mr Laurance a Merchant residing in London: Smith had opened that also it being too heavy to be sent out by the three-penny Post— It was from the Department of State, and contained a despatch from the Brothers Baring and Co. and a Letter to me, from James Monroe Secretary of State; dated 23. October. directing me to make application to the British Government in the case of the Ship Hope, Obed Chase, Master, which during the late War was taken by the Boats of a British Ship of War; in the Harbour of Buenos Ayres.— The same case upon which more than a year ago I had an application from Mr Laurance but could then do nothing.— Copies of the Papers of the case, are enclosed with the instruction from Mr Monroe— My wife went out with Winthrop to execute some Commission for Mrs Eustis.— Mr Plettner the Bavarian concerning whom Mr Pfeffel wrote me last week called— He said Pfeffel had yesterday promised him to meet him this day at my Office, at 3. O’Clock.— But Pfeffel did not come. Plettner waited for him until past four and then went away. He appeared to be much distressed, and wanted to go to America, or any where for subsistence. An American named Dunkin came and took a Passport for himself and a Servant to go to Calais and Boulogne. Mr Parry came to enquire if any answer had been received to his many Communications and parcels transmitted to Commodore Barney— There was none— Parry said he had finally determined to go to America, and should embark in the Venus, a vessel that is to sail for New-York about the last of January— Mr Laurance called about the case of the Ship Hope, and I promised to address to Lord Castlereagh, a Note concerning it. Laurance said he had applied for the interposition of the Spanish Ambassador, who had refused it, on the ground that at the time when the capture was made, Buenos Ayres was a Colony in rebellion against Spain; and if it had not been, the Hope could not have been there— He had also applied to the agent of the Buenos Ayres Government here; but he told him that he was not recognized at this Court, and that no representation from him could have any effect— I wrote to G. Boyd at Paris, and left the Packets for him and Harris to be forwarded by Smith— We left the Office at five, and came home in a Storm of wind and rain. Brought out with me Lord Byron’s third Canto of Child Harold, which I read after dinner.— He is perhaps the most fashionable Poet of the Age, but his poetry is not made I think, of lasting materials— The subject of this Poem allows him to be as desultory as he pleases. So it treats of himself, his daughter, the battle of Waterloo, Napoleon, Major Howard, Ehrenbreitstein, General Marceau, the Rhine, the Lake of Geneva, Clarens, Rousseau, Gibbon, Voltaire, and a Lady in England whom Lord Byron loves, but who is not his wife— The train of thought is original, wild, romantic, and bordering on distraction. The versification singular but habitually running the sense from line to line; to the utter discomfiture of Harmony.— The sentiment sometimes tender, but always with a mixture of gloom and fierceness— The best Stanza’s in this Canto, are those upon Napoleon.

11. VII:15. I was engaged from my rising hour, with the interval of Breakfast until half past three O’Clock upon this journal and the index volume. Walk to Ealing and Brentford.— Wrote to Mr Maury the Consul at Liverpool, answering at once several Letters from him. Read this Evening several Articles of the Supplementary Monthly Review for October 1815— The superior merit of the Edinburgh Review, appears to have sunk into oblivion all the elder periodical critics. I found here among the rest an Article upon the Marquis Cordier de Lannai’s circumspherical Theory of the beautiful, a work which I read in Russia, and to which, whimsical as it is, the Reviewer has not done justice.

12. V:45. Since the shortening of the days, during the present Season, I have indulged the indolent habit of waiting for the Morning daylight to rise from bed— That is now till between seven and eight O’Clock. The consequence has been a great abridgment of my useful occupations. The shaking of my hand likewise increases upon me, so that I write more slow and with more difficuty almost from day to day. The ring which I now use is of essential service in steadying my hand, but it rather slackens than quickens the movement of the pen.— It takes me as much time to write one page now, as it did to write two three years ago. I therefore this Morning made the attempt to resume the practice of rising before day; and I wrote a couple of hours before Sunrise; by Candle-light. It gained time; but I did not use to advantage the hours between breakfast and my walking hour— There was a storm of wind and rain with short intervals the whole day— I walked to Brentford and Ealing, partly while it held up, and partly through the Showers. Wrote a Letter to my Mother. In the Evening I read several Articles in an old Monthly Review, and several Chapters in Pillet’s book upon England; a work strongly marked by resentment, and angry Passions; a hideous Caricature of English Society and manners, but with many features of strong resemblance to the original.

13. VI— We had just finished our breakfast when Mr Christopher Hughes drove up to the door. He has the appointment of Secretary of Legation to the American Mission at Stockholm, and during the absence of Mr Russell the Minister, is to act as Chargé d’Affaires. He brought me despatches from the Secretary of State, Mr Monroe, of 1. and 2. November. a letter of the same date from R. Forrest—a Letter to my wife from her Sister Buchanan; and a Note from Mr Baker the British Consul General at Washington; enclosing a Letter, to Hughes himself. As I did not open the packets until after he went away, I lost the opportunity of giving him this Letter— A file of the National Intelligencer from 17 to 31. October; and a bundle of Baltimore Patriots of the close of October and beginning of November. Hughes sailed from Baltimore about the 5th. of November, and landed three days since at Dover. His wife is with him and he asked for my advice with respect to the manner of their proceeding to Stockholm. He is determined not to cross the North sea to Gothenburg or even to Cuxhaven with his wife at this Season of the year. His inclination is to pass six weeks or two Months here; about the same time in Paris, and then to proceed through Germany, with the good roads and mild weather of Spring, to Sweden— He was here about two hours, conversing upon a variety of topics, and after he went away the Letters and Newspapers he had left absorbed all the remainder of the Morning— So I lost again all the benefit of early rising in regard to occupation— The hour for my walk between three and four came unawares, and after my return from it I had leisure only to write the short journal of yesterday— After dinner I read a few Chapters of Pillet— George spent the whole Evening abroad. I received this morning a Letter from T. Auldjo the Consul at Cowes, about giving his bond.

14. VI: I had but just risen, this morning and it was not day light, when my Sons John and Charles came home from school. The Christmas Holidays commence this day week; but as during the last week of the term there is little or nothing done at School, the boys have prevailed upon us to consent that they should come home this day. One of our horses trod upon the Coachman Benjamin Jobbern’s foot the day before yesterday— He wrote yesterday to Mr Clarke, of whom I hire my horses, asking him to send out a man to take his place for a few days. The man came this morning. I received by the first Morning’s Post, a Note from Mr Pfeffel the Bavarian Minister, mentioning that a Te Deum would be performed by the Chaplains of that Legation, for the Marriage of the Emperor of Austria, with the Princess Charlotte of Bavaria, and enclosing two tickets that I might attend it, if I should think proper. But on the tickets eleven O’Clock was marked as the hour for the ceremony, and it was near ten when I received them. Of course, I could not attend— I sent by my Son John some verses to Ellen Nicholas upon her birth-day; which she had requested me to write; and went into London with my wife. We called at Thomas’s Hotel in Berkeley Square, to see Mr and Mrs Hughes— He told us yesterday that they had lodgings in Bond-Street, But intended if they could, to move to Thomas’s in the course of the day. They were however not there when we called, and having forgotten the number in Bond Street which Hughes had mentioned, we were disappointed in the intention of paying them our visits. We went to the Office in Craven Street; where I found a card from a Mr Barclay an English Gentleman, with two Letters which he had brought me, from my brother; dated 29. October at Philadelphia—one merely introducing Barclay, and the other upon business— There was also a Note from Count Palmella the Portuguese Ambassador enclosing a Packet for Mr Correa de Serra, the Portuguese Minister in the United States, which he requests me to forward— Mr Winthrop came in for half an hour while we were there— Mr Smith took the Papers concerning the ship Hope, by my desire to Mr Laurence in Gold Square. I found upon examination of those Papers, that mention was made in them of a Letter of Protection given for her, by Mr Foster then the British Minister in the United States— There was copy of a Letter from Foster to Dr Mitchill promising this Letter; but no copy of the Letter itself— As it would be an important document to refer to, in the application to the British Government in behalf of the Hope I desired Smith to ascertain from Laurence whether this Letter of protection or of recommendation from Foster was among the papers taken in the Ship, and now before the Court of Admiralty; and if so to obtain a copy of it for me. For which purpose I have postponed addressing a Note to Lord Castlereagh on the subject. Smith told me that Mr Pfeffel had himself called yesterday at the Office, to invite me to attend his Te Deum— The Carriage came for us at a quarter before four O’Clock. I got out between the third and fourth mile-stone, and walked thence home, which I reached before six. The day was fine and clear, but in the Evening there came up a violent tempest of wind and rain. After dinner I read several Scenes of Ben Johnson’s Epicoene, or Silent woman; a strange representation of manners. I found a considerable larceny from Juvenal’s sixth Satire—

15. VI: Received this Morning a Letter from Coll. Aspinwall the Consul, relative to the limitation of the number of passengers in American vessels— Attended Church with my three Sons. Mr Carr read Prayers for the third Sunday of Advent, and Mr Milman preached, from Revelations 1.7. “Behold he cometh with Clouds; and every eye shall see him, and they also which pierced him: and all kindreds of the Earth shall wail because of him. Even so, Amen.” A further continuation of the discourse upon the three Advents of Christ— The first to create the world; the second to redeem the world; and the third which will be to judge the world— This third advent was the particular subject of this day’s Sermon, and the preacher made some attempt to describe the day of Judgment. Not however either striking or pathetic— Ellen, Laura, Charlotte and Sophia Nicholas, with the Doctor’s Ward, Annette Mansell and a young man named Hall, were here after Church— Ellen thanked me for her Birth-day verses. Caroline, the eldest daughter is unwell. I walked to Brentford before dinner; and in the Evening read an Act of Sheridan’s Critic. There was a violent gale with heavy rain, all Night; but it subsided and cleared away this Morning— The day was fine.

16. VI:45. At dawning day; by which much of the Morning was again lost. I nevertheless wrote to the Secretary of State, despatch number 63— A Letter to Messrs Cresswell and Addams of Doctors Commons, and a Note to Count Palmella, the Portuguese ambassador. Walked to Ealing and Brentford, and dined with George at Mr Copland’s at Gunnersbury— My wife being unwell had sent an excuse yesterday. The company were, Major and Mrs Morison, Miss Ramsey, two Misses Moore, Mr Birnie, a Bow-Street Magistrate, Mr Clifton, Mr Gordon, and a Mr Rose, a partner with Mr Copland in some of his concerns—with Mr Copland’s three Sons, Alexander, William, and Francis. Mr Birnie is a Scotchman, and Mrs Morison, was much enchanted with her late visit to Scotland; so that there was much Scottish Conversation— No Politics, and no collisions of Opinion— Mrs Copland played on the Piano and Harp after dinner, and sung— Miss Ramsey likewise sung. We came home between eleven and twelve— I found a Letter from J. Maury the Consul at Liverpool, in reply to my last to him about Brewer.

17. VI: I went into London, with my Sons George and John. Found J. A. Smith unwell with a very severe Cold and Cough. I went into the City to the Counting House of the Brothers Baring and Co. 8. Bishopsgate Street. Mr Alexander Baring, is at his Country Seat in Hampshire the Grange. I walked back to Craven Street, and found at the door of my Office, in a Carriage, the two Misses Vaughan, with Mr Petty Vaughan who came to take leave— He is going immediately to Madeira, Jamaica and the United States— We were at home to dinner at half past six. I made two or three attempts to read after dinner but was obliged to put my books aside. Having kept late hours last Night; and risen early this Morning, I was quite unable to command my attention for reading this Evening.

18. VII:15. By daylight. The habit into which I have fallen of waiting for daylight to rise, is like all other evil habits more easily formed than shaken off. My wife was unwell in the Night, and I had imperfect rest myself. But the day from breakfast time was with sufficient assiduity devoted to writing. I answered the Letters on file from W. Shaler; from him and Commodore Chauncey, from T. Auldjo, Consul at Cowes, from James Holmes formerly Consul at Belfast, and from R. Aspland—to thank him for the present of his publications; and for the Copy of the Memoirs of Brand Hollis, sent me by Dr Disney— I walked to Brentford and Ealing; and after dinner read a few pages of Pillet.

19. V:45. Received this Morning a Letter from Coll. Aspinwall the Consul, requesting my interference to obtain from the Lords of the Treasury a permission for the Samoset, and American vessel of 256 Tons, now here, in ballast and ready for Sea, to take on board a number not exceeding one hundred, of destitute American Seamen, to be conveyed to the United States— He sent me a Copy of his Letter to the Lords of the Treasury, dated the 13th. instant, and to which he has received no answer. I wrote a Note immediately to Lord Castlereagh on the subject, and sent William with it to London— He left it at Lord Castlereagh’s house, corner of St. James’s Square; his Lordship being out of town, but to return this Evening. William called at my Office in Craven Street, and brought out with him, a Letter from William Temple Franklin, with a copy which he requests me to accept, of the Private Correspondence of Dr Franklin, which he has just published, and another copy which he asks me to forward to Mr Monroe— And a Letter from L. H. Halloran, also with two Volumes published by him which he presents to my acceptance, and which relate principally to himself. He Styles himself the victim of persecution, and renews offers of entering into the service of the United States, which he made about nine years ago to Mr Monroe, and renewed in 1812 to Mr Russell. In the interval between the two periods he was a chaplain in the British army at the Cape of Good Hope, and in the year 1810. was banished from that Colony, by a sentence of the Dutch Court of Justice, for libels on General Grey, a brother of Lord Grey and then Lieutenant Governor at the Cape— One of his volumes is merely an account of all the proceedings in this case. I walked to Hanwell and Ealing, through several successive flights of Snow. There was a new Moon at 11 last Night, and it is immediately followed by a strongly marked change of weather. This Evening was clear and cold. I wrote Letters to my Mother and Brother; and after dinner read some pages of Pillet—

20. V:45. The Morning was clear and cold, and I saw from my windows the same Constellations that I had observed with George on the Evening of the 26th. of April last. I saw Jupiter newly risen. He is yet in Libra, but close upon the borders of the Scorpion. I went to London alone. Called at Thomas’s Hotel Berkeley Square, to see Mr and Mrs Hughes, but was told they were gone out. Stopp’d at Richardson’s 96 Pall Mall, and thence proceeded to my Office in Craven-Street. I found Smith almost entirely free from his cough and looking well. There was a letter from F. E. Montreal, with a bill of lading of the box containing the books which he sent me by the ship Holderness— A Letter from Hughes, dated ship Emily at Sea in November, requesting me to furnish him a list of Books on General Modern History, and National and diplomatic Law; enough to employ his time in reading for a couple of years— A note from him written yesterday, promising to come out with Mrs Hughes and see us this day; and a subsequent note to Smith, written last Evening, saying that he found himself unwell, and he feared they would not be able to come out this day. Smith said the Danish Minister Mr Bourke had called yesterday at the Office, and told him that an official communication had been made from the Russian to the Danish Government, stating that the affair respecting the Russian Consul at Philadelphia, Kosloff had been settled to the entire satisfaction of the Emperor Alexander— I called at the Tavistock Hotel, Covent-Garden to see P. V. Ogden, and F. B. Ogden, the latter of whom brought me a Letter of Introduction from my brother—left Cards for them, and called to see Major Mercer at Brunet’s Hotel, in Leicester Square. He has been these two Months almost constantly confined to his chamber with rhumatic complaints, but is now recovering— He told me that General Boyd arrived this morning at that house; and he should call upon him, although Boyd and Scott had been at great variance with each other, and he, Mercer had felt himself obliged to take the part of Scott— The Cause of their difference was that in the reduction of the Army after the Peace, Scott upon being consulted by the Government with regard to Boyd, that given it as his opinion, that both his conduct during the war, and his character with regard to personal courage were such that he ought not to be continued in the service. This opinion though confidentially given had come unfortunately to Boyd’s ears; he had called upon Scott to say whether he had expressed it, and Scott had been obliged to avow that he had. It was the general opinion of the army.— After Scott came to Europe he had heard that Boyd had been loud in his complaints against him, but since then he had heard nothing of him— We had various other conversation, and as I was coming out of the Hotel, I met Mr Leavenworth going in— On my return to Craven Street I found Colonel Aspinwall at the Office— He had called to enquire if the permission for the Samoset could probably be obtained as soon as Monday. I told him of the Note that I had sent yesterday to Lord Castlereagh, to which I have as yet received no reply— He said to morrow was a Holiday and no business would be done at the Custom-House. It is St. Thomas’s day; and the day of annual election for the Common Council of the City of London. Coll. Aspinwall spoke of his accounts; and said the expences for destitute Seamen, during the year would amount to eleven or twelve thousand Pounds Sterling. He also said he should charge in his accounts the fees paid for his exequatur— I reached home between six and seven; and after dinner read a few pages of Pillet.

21. VI:45. Fahrenheit 24. The day of the Winter Solstice— A clear morning, and I saw the Sun rise from my Cabinet windows. My wife and George went to London. I received from J. A. Smith a Letter enclosing a Note from Lord Castlereagh in answer to mine about the permission for the Samoset. Smith had opened it, and written to Coll. Aspinwall the substance of its contents, which are, that Lord Castlereagh had directed a copy of my Note to be sent to the Lords of the Treasury with a request that orders might be forthwith given in compliance with my desire. I walked to Ealing, Gunnersbury and Brentford— My wife and George returned home about seven. George brought me a Letter from L. Harris at St. Petersburg of 22. November, confirming the account which we had received that the affair relating to the Russian Consul at Philadelphia, Kosloff had been settled to the satisfaction of the Emperor. Harris says that he expects the arrival of his successor, Mr Pinkney in a few days. That the Secretary of the Legation, Mr King, had already arrived; and that he Harris had sent Mr Coles, on, as a Courier, to embark from Holland or France as he might find an opportunity— And also a Letter from W. H. Nevett, of the house of T. Dickason and Co. to Smith, enquiring whether there is any prospect of effecting a settlement of the case of the William and Mary, without a decision of the Admiralty Court— While we were at dinner the Evening post, brought a large budget of Letters from my father, mother and brother, and from several other persons in America, brought by General Boyd, my old friend J. M. Forbes, and John P. B. Storer, a son of Woodbury Storer of Portland.
Among the Letters was one from Forbes himself— One from Mr Monroe strongly recommending General Boyd to my civilities; and one from Elijah Wood, Secretary of an agricultural Society in the County of Kennebeck, making several enquiries concerning the management of bees, and the raising of honey in Russia— The Evening was fine and the conjunction of the Moon and Venus remarkable in the sky.

22. VI:45. Fahrenheit 18. We all attended Church. Prayers for the fourth Sunday in Advent were read by Mr. Carr; and the Sermon was preached by Dr Nicholas, from Matthew XI:3—“Art thou he that should come, or do we look for another?” A very sensible discourse in the cold unimpassioned manner, without pretension of eloquence— The day was fine— I walked to Hanwell and Ealing. George’s schoolmates Robert and James Chichester dined with us, and the four elder Misses Nicholas spent the Evening here.
