div.p:
23. VI: Fahrenheit at 32 and rising to a thaw. By the second Post, after twelve at Noon, I received a Note from Lord Castlereagh dated on Saturday and requesting me to call on him at eleven O’Clock this Morning. I immediately went into London, and at three O’Clock when I reached his house found him still at home. He told me that as he was going out of town for two or three days, he had sent for me to tell me that he had not forgotten the promise that he had made me before he went to Ireland that the subject of my Note of 27. September, proposing the Negotiation of a Commercial Treaty, should be taken up by this Government immediately after his return— That it had been taken up. Two Cabinet Councils had already been held upon it; and as it embraced a variety of important objects, as soon as they could be sufficiently matured for instructions to given him under which he could discuss them with me, I should hear from him again— I said, if the general determination had been taken to enter upon the Negotiation, there could be no objection to taking time for arranging particulars. He replied that his present purpose was merely to assure me, that he was mindful of his promise, and that the Government were earnestly engaged in the consideration of the proposal— He then enquired if I had any late accounts from the other side of the water, and what had been the state of our Harvest. I told him I was informed that the Indian Corn, had almost universally failed; and in a very great degree. The other grains had suffered little; but as in all the Eastern, and even in some of the Southern States, that article formed the principal ingredient in the bread of the most numerous class of our population, a scanty harvest of it, would necessarily affect the consumption and the price of the other materials for bread— He said their harvest here had been partially bad; there would turn out to be enough for the consumption of the People; but he was very much afraid that would not be the case in the interior of Germany; where he heard the distress was very great. I said I heard the Harvest in France was also very bad— He said it was so in some parts of France, and good in others; but the vines had universally and entirely failed— In Ireland, the harvest was worse than here, and at one moment they had been much alarmed for the crop of potatoes, the article which formed the whole subsistence of the great majority of their population. There had been a severe frost which it had been apprehended had cut them off to an alarming degree; but fortunately the frost had been preceded by a deep fall of Snow, which had prevented it from penetrating deep into the ground and had saved the potatoes— From this topic he passed immediately to that of the Slave trade, which he said was now carrying on to a very great extent and in a shocking manner— That a great number of vessels for it, had been fitted out in our Southern States; and that the barbarities of the trade were even more atrocious than they had been before the abolition of it had been attempted. The vessels sailed under the flags of the Nations which still allowed the trade, Spain and Portugal; they were very small and sailed like lightening.— One vessel of 120 tons taken by Sir James Yeo, had six hundred Slaves on board. She had been out three days and there were thirty of them already dead. These vessels escape capture, by the rapidity of their operations. They have agents on the slave Coast, who purchase and collect the slaves together on the shore. The vessels occasionally approach, until they see on the shore the flag flying which is the signal that the Agents are ready with the slaves— Then they go and take them on board, and disappear again in the course of a very few hours— If on approaching the land they do not see the flag, they immediately go off again and remain some time out of sight of land. The slaves when taken are carried to Brezil, the Coast of South America, and the Havanna. Neither Spain nor Portugal, even if they favoured the total abolition of the traffic have a force adequate to the suppression of it, as thus practiced— For an extent of a thousand miles on the Coast of Africa, Portugal has not more than two armed vessels, and for another thousand Miles on the Coast of South America perhaps two more— It is impossible they should be adequate to put down a traffic thus carried on; what he, Lord Castlereagh had thought of, and believed would be ultimately necessary was, that the Nations which were agreed upon the abolition, should authorize, the capture of the slave trading vessels, by the armed force of other Nations, but
that the trial should be by Commissioners, not exclusively of the capturing Nation— That each of the Powers for instance should appoint one “Commissaire Juge,” and that whenever a capture was made, it should be tried by the Commissary-judge of the capturing Nation, and the one of the Nation under whose flag, the Slave-trading vessel should be taken. And if they could not agree, then to call in the Commissaire-juge of a third and indifferent party to decide. This had been the course adopted, with regard to the claims of the subjects of the several powers, upon France, under the Treaties of Paris. There was a French Comissaire-juge—one of the claimant’s Nation; and if they could not agree, the Commissaire-juge of a third party was added to come to the decision— It was found that the business was thus done without difficulty or inconvenience— Lord Castlereagh did not say it was his intention to propose that the United-States should take part in this system, and have their Commissaire-juge among the rest; so that I heard all his observations on the subject without thinking it necessary to make any reply— What led to his speaking about the slave trade was my congratulating him on the result of Lord Exmouth’s expedition against Algiers— I said that the United States had still an arrangement to make, of their relations with Algiers: that Mr Shaler and Commodore Chauncey were the Commissioners appointed for that purpose, and that I had been informed by the Secretary of State, that their Instructions authorised them, in the renewal of the Treaty to consent to a modification of the Articles, which had been objected to by this Country, so that they should not be taken as applicable contrary to the engagements of previous Treaties between Great-Britain and Algiers— I had been highly gratified that the success of Lord Exmouth’s attack had been such as I had anticipated, and as the system of Barbary warfare appeared to be now broken down, I hoped it would never again be suffered to revive— He said that the success had been equal to their most sangwine expectations— That when Lord Exmouth was first sent there measures of hostility had not been authorised, owing to the considerations which he had mentioned to me at the time— Afterwards, when they had ceased to operate, the expedition had been undertaken with a full knowledge of its difficulties and hazards. Lord Exmouth himself had been asked whether it could be attempted with a prospect of success; and had answered that it might be done. He had told them how it could be done, and precisely as he had effected it—by running his ship, close in to the shore, directly opposite to the battery, and see which would hold out longest, the stone or the wood— It had happily proved a successful experiment, and it might be hoped would lead to the breaking up of Christian Slavery in Africa.— He wished there were a prospect equally fair of breaking up the African Slave-trade; and then he proceeded to the remarks just noted— I asked him if he had any late despatches from Mr Bagot. He said, to some time in October when he was about returning to Washington. There had been some discussion between him and Mr Monroe about the fisheries; but nothing definitively adjusted— I observed to him that there were several objects relating to individual interests, upon which I had representations to make to him, and should shortly address him in writing— In one of them the United States themselves had an interest— I spoke of a number of Custom-house, revenue-bonds executed by Citizens of the United-States, which had been taken by the British at Moose-Island in July 1814. These bonds had been carried to Halifax, and not only condemned as prize, but some or all of them had been put in suit; one of the obligors had been arrested and held to bail, before the judge of the Admiralty Court at Halifax; who had pronounced a decree against him— There was an appeal in his behalf now pending in the high Court of appeals here. The other obligors being in the United-States, the process of the Admiralty Court at Halifax could not reach them— But living on the borders of the British Province their affairs occasionally called them there; but could not step over the boundary so long as this sentence should be hanging over them— The United States had proceeded, and recovered the monies due upon these bonds from the obligors. I understood it was the opinion of most respectable lawyers here, that the sentence of the Admiralty Court at Halifax could not be supported; and it was desirable if possible to have the case taken out, and settled, without waiting for a formal decision of the high Court of appeals— Another case was that of the William and Mary, a vessel taken at Cadix, within the Spanish Jurisdiction, and condemned by the Vice-Admiralty Court at Gibraltar— It was also pending in the high Court of Appeals. The Spanish Ambassador had already presented to him Lord Castlereagh two Notes, claiming the restitution of this property, on the ground of the Jurisdiction. There was no doubt that the claim of Spanish Jurisdiction was valid— The evidence in support of it was clear and complete, and the persons interested in the property, wished the case to be taken out of Court, and settled.
A third case was that of a vessel called the Hope, fitted out at New York, and despatched on a Voyage of discovery in the year 1812. just before the Commencement of the late War. She had a special Passport from the Government of the United States, and particular Letters of recommendation from the foreign Ministers then residing in the United States, among which was one from Mr Foster the British Minister.— She was taken, by boats from a British armed vessel in the harbour of Buenos Ayres, within neutral jurisdiction— In this case however the Spanish Ambassador declined interfering in behalf of the jurisdiction, upon the ground that Buenos Ayres was then in a state of revolt against the authority of Spain, and that by the Laws of Spain neither the capturing nor the captured vessel had any right or business to be there— Lord Castlereagh said that if all the British Ships that had been there were to be made answerable for it Spain would have work enough upon her hands— I replied that this was the reason alledged by the Spanish Ambassador for refusing to interpose on account of the jurisdiction: but the capture had certainly been made within the neutral boundary; and the voyage was one of that description which by the usages of civilized Nations is allowed to be unmolested in time of War. The parties interested in this vessel were also desirous that the case should be taken out of the Admiralty Court and settled ministerially. We are very much in the habit, said Lord Castlereagh, of referring such cases to the kings Advocate for a Report, and if you will write a line to me about them, I will see that they shall be attended to— Hereupon I took my leave, and he said he was going into the Country this Evening. I went to Craven Street— Smith was out, but came in a few minutes afterwards. He had just been to see Mr and Mrs A. H. Everett who arrived last Evening from Boston— I paid visits to General Boyd and Mr Storer, at Brunet’s Hotel and to J. M. Forbes, next door to it, in Leicester Square— They were all out. I left cards of invitation for them to dine with us on Wednesday. I next went to 45 Dover Street Piccadilly, where I found Mr and Mrs Everett— He gave me several Packets of despatches and Letters with which he had been charged for me. Everett returned from Amsterdam to Boston last Summer for the purpose of being married to Miss Lucretia Peabody of Exeter, and has now come back with her. They sailed from Boston the 27th. of last Month in the Galen, and had a passage of twenty-two days to Dover, where they landed. Everett has despatches for St. Petersburg, and was instructed to carry them there as a special Messenger— But hearing that the affair of Kosloff, the Russian Consul at Philadelphia, had been settled to the Emperor’s Satisfaction, he thinks it will not be necessary for him to proceed. I invited them to dine with us on Wednesday, but they had just before accepted an invitation from S. Williams— I returned to Craven Street, where I found Parry, the man who is going with his family to America— He now lives at Feversham in Kent, and he gives a gloomy picture of the situation of the Country. He had scarcely left the Office when a man came in who did not give his name, but said he had heard the American Government were giving encouragement to Cotton manufactures; and he came in behalf of a Mr. Marshall a Cotton Printer, and perhaps the most skilful man of the trade in all England; who was very desirous of going to America, and forming an establishment of that Nature there. I told him that the American Government gave no direct encouragement to any kind of manufactures: they took no part in such establishments; but they were bottomed altogether upon private enterprize. The only aid they received from the Government was by the means of duties upon articles of foreign manufacture which stood in competition with them, and I ought to add that by my late accounts from the United States, the present would be a very unfavourable moment for the establishment of such a manufacture, as those already existing there were now suffering very severely, by the competition of the imported British Manufactures which were also selling at a heavy loss to the importers of them. He said he was aware there had been losses on Articles of Cotton manufacture sent to America; but he had supposed that was owing entirely to the inferior quality of the goods. That many of the manufacturers had certainly got into the habit of sending out Articles of such wretched quality that it was no wonder they met with losses upon the sales. I said that was not the only causes of those losses; but the market had been overstocked, and in consequence of it the manufacturers of the Country were suffering as well as the importers. He thanked me for the information and left me. I had thus been detained at the Office till six-O’Clock, and it was almost eight when I reached home. After dinner I opened the packets which had been delivered to me by Mr Everett— There was one of Letters from my Mother to 26. Novr. The rest were despatches from the Secretary of State— Two of 14. and two of 16. November, with voluminous copies of Papers—upon the
affair of Kosloff— A correspondence between Mr Monroe and Mr Bagot, upon the subject of armaments on the Canadian Lakes— The report of the Court of Inquiry on the rencounter between the Peacock, and the Nautilus, an armed vessel belonging to the British East-India Company in the Straits of Sunda in June 1815: and papers relating to Crosby’s claim, with the National Intelligencer from 2 to 14. November. I was employed after dinner in reading the papers relative to Kosloff.

24— VI: I intended to have gone to London this Morning; but the weather proving bad, and the necessity of writing, pressing upon my time, I made up my Packet for the Secretary of State; with despatch N. 64. and sent William with them to London. I also wrote to W. T. Franklin, thanking him for the copy that he has sent me of his Grandfather’s Correspondence. While taking my usual daily walk, I called at Dr Nicholas’s, and settled with him the bill for the last half-year’s schooling of my three Sons— He told me I had been the first last Summer; and was again the first now— It is one of the terms of admittance at his School, that three Months notice shall be given before taking a scholar away, or ten-guineas to be paid. I told the Doctor it was not improbable, I might return to American in the Spring, in which case I should take all my family with me; I wished him therefore to take it as notice now; that I should take my Sons from school, if I should leave this Country. He said that under my particular Circumstances, he should not take advantage of any shortness of notice; and he had seen in the newspapers, that I was to be the Secretary of State, under the next President— I told him that Newspaper authority for anticipated appointments in America, was not to be relied upon, but various circumstances might bring me to the determination of going home the next year— As the Doctor was at dinner when I called, I did not detain him; but pursued my walk round by Gunnersbury, with George, whom I had met at Dr Goodenough’s corner, and who turned and walked with me. I had received this Morning, a Letter from A. H. Everett written yesterday before I had called upon him, to inform me of his arrival and having despatches for me; a Note from General Neuffer the Wurtemberg Minister, containing an application for authentic information concerning a Wurtemberger named Schwarz, deceased at New-York in the year 1797—and a note from Mr William Jones Burdett, inviting me to dine with him next Saturday. When William returned from London in the Evening he brought out a Letter from Messrs. Cresswell and Addams, with their account against the United States, and a large packet of vouchers. A Letter from the Brothers Baring and Co. respecting an American claim before the Lords of the Treasury, for a vessel called the Lion, and Cargo; the Agency for which is transferred to them, from the house of Alexander Glennie and Son, which has failed— A Letter from J. A. Smith, mentioning that the Miss Vaughan’s had called to invite us, to dine with them next Thursday to meet Mr and Mrs. A. H. Everett; and a Letter from S. Bourne at Amsterdam, mentioning that he has heard I am to be Secretary of State, and asking for a place in that Department— In September 1815. I received a Letter from H. G. Spafford of the State of New-York, dated 8. August 1815. in which he says he had been the preceding Winter at Washington, where the President had told him they were intending to reserve for me the best Office in the gift of Administration, as long as possible without injury to the public service. As this referred to a period previous to my appointment for the mission to England, I did not understand what was meant by it; but supposed it was an intention contingent upon my return home immediately after the Peace of Ghent.— After this, the first intimation that I had on this subject was from G. Boyd, who when last here told me there was a talk about the Offices at Washington, that the place of Secretary of State, would be offered to me, by Mr Monroe.— The next was from Mr John Winthrop on the 5th. of this Month. Since then it has been announced in all the Newspapers here, as extracted from American Newspapers, that it is settled— I am to be recalled, and to be Secretary of State— Lastly my Mother in her Letter of 26. November last, mentions a message from the President, by the Secretary of the Navy, that if Mr A. returned, that Office would be offered to him— Spafford’s Letter had entirely escaped my recollection until within these few days. I had no expectation or belief that the Office would be offered to me, until the receipt of my Mother’s Letter; and now I consider it still as a matter of great uncertainty. The question whether I ought to accept the place if it should be offered is not without difficulties in my Mind— A doubt of my competency for it, is very sincerely entertained, and ought perhaps to be decisive. At all Events, if I could be rationally justified in accepting it, if offered, I perceive no propriety in taking any step whatever to seek it. The person who is to nominate for the Office
will be Mr Monroe, and from him I have received no such intimation— Nor any from the present President, with an express authority to ask me for an answer— If Mr Monroe’s real intention be to propose to me the acceptance of the Office, I think it but consistent with what is due to my own character, as well as conformable to my own doubts whether I am fitted to discharge the heavy and laborious duties of the Office, to wait for a direct communication from him, signifying his intention, before I take any step, on the presumption that it will be carried into effect— I employed the Evening in reading the National Intelligencer’s received by Mr Everett. I wrote a Note to Mr Burdett, accepting his invitation to dinner on Saturday; but my wife declined that of the Miss Vaughan’s for Thursday; they having removed to Clapham Common distant at least twelve Miles from our house; a distance which she thinks too great for going to a dinner at this Season of the year.

25. VII:15. Christmas day. I rose with the dawn. Since I undertook to resume the practice of early rising, on the twelfth of this Month, I have been very irregular in the practice, and find it more difficult to carry into effect than it formerly was. The morning occupation intrenched so much upon the day, that I omitted attending Church— I answered Hughes’s Letter, asking for a list of Books, and walked to Ealing and Brentford— Mr and Mrs Hughes. P. V. Ogden, Mr Rotch and J. A. Smith dined with us. I had invited T. B. Barclay, General Boyd, E Copeland, Mr and Mrs Everett. J. M. Forbes, Major Mercer, F. B. Ogden Mr Rotch’s son, Mr Storer, Coll. Talmadge, and J. Winthrop. I had no answer from Talmadge, and suppose therefore he is not in London; from all the others we had apologies. Our small company left us before eleven O’Clock— This morning I received a Letter from Jos: Hall of Boston, which had been brought by A. H. Everett, and which he had overlooked when he gave me the others; and Smith brought me out a Letter from my brother of 17. Novr. marked as a ship Letter from Liverpool, and forwarded by Gulian Ludlow from New-York.

26. V:15. Before breakfast this Morning, I finished the Index to the third and fourth Volumes of my Diary, which I began the 26th. of July last, and have continued without intermission to this day. I began with five lines a day, but soon finding how slow my progress at that rate must be increased the daily number of lines until the last three days when I have written twenty-four— For nearly three Months it has absorbed all my Morning hours, and often encroached upon those of the day. I have now completed the Index back to the 5th. of August 1809. the day when I last embarked from the U.S. for Europe, and when I began the third Volume of my Diary. The preceding Volumes are in America, and the Index, if ever carried farther backward can only be completed when I shall have access again to them— The day was bad; but during an interval from the Storm, I walked to Gunnersbury and Brentford. My Sons George and John are to take lessons of Geography during the holidays, four days a week from Mr Heslop, one of the Masters of Dr Nicholas’s school, and went first to him this day. I answered the Letters from Baring Brothers and Co. concerning the case of the Lion and Cargo, and from L. Halloran on his proposal to enter into the service of the United States— Evening idle.

27. VII:45. Just before Sunrise. And although released from occupation upon my Index, the Journal still employs all my leisure. It had gone in arrears from Tuesday, and will require the assiduity of four or five days to bring it up. It absorbed almost entirely that of this day. I received a Letter from James S. Glennie, referring to one of 4. May last, from the house of Alexr. Glennie Son and Co (which house he says is no longer in existence now) with documents relative to the case of the Sloop, Mary & Cargo, belonging to Clark and Kempton of Philadelphia, pending in the Admiralty Court of Appeals— An instruction has been received from Kempton, surviving partner of that house, to withdraw the Appeal, and inform me, that I may commence a negotiation with the Government for the restoration of the property. The Procter has therefore he says been directed to withdraw the Appeal, and he requests my interference, and attention to the case— Also a Letter from Robert Mowbray of Leith— He applied soon after my arrival in this Country, for the appointment of American Consul at that place, and was strongly recommended for it, by Jos. Pitcairn— Some Months afterwards he wrote to me, enquiring what had been the success of his application. I informed him that it had been forwarded by me to the American Secretary of State from whom I had received no answer concerning it—nor have I received any to this day— He now refers to the rumours in the Public Prints, that I am to return to America to fill an important Office there, in which case he asks a continuance of my good offices, and in the mean time would be glad to accept a provisional appointment of Consul at Leith from me— I walked to Acton by the way of Gunnersbury and, returned home by the way of Ealing. Wrote a short Letter to my Mother; and after dinner copied off about forty lines of my epistle to her; an Epistle yet left unfinished, and which may perhaps always remain so— Upon a reperusal, after the interval of a Month during which it has been laid aside, I find it altogether too flat to be sent across the Atlantic.

28. IV: It is not my will, that is thus capricious, in varying the hour of my rising; but the accident, which causes me to awake at such different hours. As I awoke this morning, I heard a repeated crowing of the Cock; from which I concluded that the day was dawning, and that of course it must be between six and seven O’Clock— It was really more than two hours before day. Shakespear’s Marcellus in Hamlet tells us “Some say that ever ’gainst that season comes, Wherein our Saviours birth is celebrated, The bird of dawning singeth all night long.” I believe there is some foundation for this remark; and I believe the cause to be, not precisely as Marcellus suggests that the Nights are then more wholesome, or the time more gracious than any other, but that the Nights are too long, for the repose which the Nature of the bird requires; that he awakes long before day and crows to cheer his ennui. So it was at least this Morning, which was clear and bright. I observed the Stars about half an hour; saw the Constellations of Virgo and Libra, very distinctly from my Cabinet windows, and discerned the crow, and many of the Stars of Hydra. Saw Jupiter rise; and expected to have seen Antares, but the day came on before he rose. I was steadily engaged upon my Journal till breakfast. Received Letters from Coll. Aspinwall and J. A. Smith. The Coll: complains that he has not yet received from the Lords of the Treasury the permission for the Samoset, and that she is lying at Gravesend at a heavy expence. He asks also an order upon the Brothers Baring and Co. for £1050 to pay for this vessel, and another for the current expences of the Office of £500. Smith’s Letter says that he had advised the young man, who brought Coll. Aspinwall’s Letter to the Office to go himself and enquire at the Treasury about the permission for the Samoset— That he had accordingly been, and was told that it would be immediately attended to; but had been neglected, not being supposed of immediate urgency— I went into London with my wife and George, who had been to Dr Nicholas’s. The Doctor he said was very suddenly seized last Evening, with the Gout in his stomach, was very dangerously ill, all Night, and not expected to live through the day. We called at the St. Petersburg Hotel, Dover Street, Piccadilly, to see Mr & Mrs Everett. They had just removed to N. 5: St. James’s Place, St. James’s Street, where we went and found them. I told Mr Everett that on reading over the copies of the despatches which he had been instructed to carry to St. Petersburg, I thought it would be most expedient for him to go there, notwithstanding the accounts received from thence, that the affair of the Russian Consul at Philadelphia, Kosloff had been settled to the Emperor’s Satisfaction. He had concluded not to go, and had left the despatches at my Office. There I found cards—from Mr Charles Everett, with a Letter from his Cousin A. H. written at Boston before he sailed. Charles Everett came in another vessels some days sooner, and arrived about a fortnight since at Liverpool—from J. C. Montgomery who comes from Ireland, with a message from Lady Morgan, and another packet from her for General La Fayette—from Mr William Latham, the partner of Mr Maury at Liverpool; and from Dr Platt of New-York— There was also a Bill from James Holmes the former Consul at Newry, drawn at twenty-one days sight, which I accepted. Mr Joy came in and sat till five— My wife and George dined at the Office; and George went to the Sans Pareil Theatre, in the Strand. I went with Mr Smith, and dined at Mr William Jones Burdett’s. N. 7. Great Cumberland Street. As we went into the house, there was a cry of fire, which proved to be only the chimney. Mrs Burdett has the appearance of being under twenty-five; and they have three infant daughters the eldest less than five years old— There was at the dinner besides Mrs. Burdett only one Lady a Mrs Wilson.— The men were Lord Cochrane, Mr Frend, Dr. Cooke of Gower-Street, a Genl: M’Donald, Mr Winthrop, and two other Gentlemen, whose names I did not ascertain, but ardent reformers. After dinner two or three other Ladies, and several Gentlemen came in, and they had Cards. The Conversation was miscellaneous, and the political part of it, marked with the greatest Moderation. Lord Cochrane, who is a man of serious deportment, and grave, but not unsocial manners told me that people were entertaining great expectations from the Meeting of Parliament, which would be disappointed. There would be some warm debates in the early part of the Session, but they would result in nothing. This has invariably been my own opinion— It was past eleven when we returned to Craven Street, where I waited about half an hour longer till George came from the theatre. We got home about half past one in the Morning. The Evening and Night were as stormy as the morning had been fair— Fahrenheit’s Thermometer before Sun-rise had been at the freezing point, but rose to rain. Dr. Nicholas was better this Evening.

29. VIII:45. A balance for the early hour of yesterday Morning. I attended Church with my three Sons. Prayers for the first Sunday after Christmas were read by Mr Milman— Mr Carr preached the Sermon, from Luke X.37.—“Go and do thou likewise.” It was an exhortation to benevolence; a moral essay. Such are all the sermons I have heard from him. No historical or critical explanations— No delineations of character. No exposition of controverted doctrines; no attempt at disputed argument, or at eloquence. Mr Carr reads with great propriety, and perfectly understands the rules of accent emphasis and inflection. But he follows the general practice of the Church of England, which excludes all impassioned eloquence from the pulpit— He gave notice that there would be Church service performed, on the day of the Circumcision, which is New-Years day, and that the Communion would be administered next Sunday— After Church we had visits from F. Nicholas and Alexr. Copeland— Dr Nicholas is almost recovered, and entirely free from pain. It was not an attack of the gout, but a sudden and very violent illness—they do not precisely know what— I walked before dinner to Brentford, and through the Sion house Park— George’s schoolmate R. Chichester, who passes the Holidays at Dr Nicholas’s dined and spent the Evening here. My occupations for the day, were much abridged by the late hour of my rising.

30. V:30. And made progress in redeeming the arrears of my Journal; which engrossed all the Morning. Wrote a Letter to Coll. Aspinwall, and enclosed to him an order upon the Baring’s for £1550. There was a steady rain almost the whole day, but I took a walk of near an hour to Brentford. Confinement to the house even one whole day when I am well is extremely irksome to me; and there is no weather in which I can willingly forego the benefit of air and exercise. I also wrote despatch 65 to S.S. and in the Evening finished the first copy of the Epistle to my Mother. It is now formed in to some shape, and no longer in the Chaos of the first draft— There are yet however two transpositions to be made, and then, if I was wise, the whole would be burnt— By this Evening’s post I received Letters—from J. Maury announcing that he had forwarded despatches by the Mail Coach— From H. Visger at Bristol, concerning his exequatur, and destitute American Seamen—from R. Forrest, of the Department of State, enclosing a packet for C. Hughes—from the Adjutant and Inspector General of United States army, Washington 19. Novr. enclosing Letters to Coll William M’Rae, and Major Sylvanus Thayer, of the Corps of Engineers, which he requests me to forward to them and says are orders recalling them— There was also an inclosure of a Letter to my wife, from one of her Sisters, directed to St: Petersburg and dated in December 1814. where it has been, and how or whence it now comes is not apparent.

31. IV: And brought up before Breakfast the arrears of this Journal, complete. Received a Note from Coll. Aspinwall, enclosing at the request of the Author an Oration delivered at the City-Hall New-York, on the 17th. of September last, the anniversary of the Sortie from Fort Erie, by Major James T. B. Romayne— I went to London with my wife— Called at Thomas’s Hotel, Berkeley-Square to see Hughes— He had removed to N. 10. Conduit Street— I went there, but he was not at his lodgings. I left a card and the packet which I received last Evening for him— I called next at the Westminster Library in Jermyn Street, and left there the Reviews that I had taken out many Months since. At Craven-Street I found a Note from Lord Holland, with a Letter and a Packet of Books from Mr Monroe, which he requests me to forward. Micklam the Tailor came in soon after, with a Note in my name desiring him to come to Ealing— I had on Saturday myself sent for him to come this day to Craven-Street— Mr Winthrop came in, and renewed his solicitations for my influence to obtain for him the Office of Consul at Hamburg. He was so very urgent in his intreaties, that I was glad to be relieved from them by the coming in of Mr J. M. Forbes, who has been afflicted both with the Gout and Scarlet fever, and has such a weakness in the knees that he walks with much difficulty. He has in his appearance many marks of premature old age. Mr Walker of the house of Greg Lindsay and Co. came to speak of the case of the Nanina, and brought a Letter from James B. Murray of New-York to J. A. Smith concerning it— The Nanina, was taken during the late war, by a British armed vessel, while her Captain and crew were in the act of saving the people of a British vessel shipwrecked, on a desert island upon the Eastern Coast of South-America. The Captain and people of the Nanina, in return for their humanity and kindness to British Subjects, endured much harsh treatment and ill-usage after their capture— The vessel was carried to Rio Janeyro, where after a long detention, the British Admiral commanding there, offered to deliver her up to the Captain, which offer was accepted. But the Admiral afterwards annexed to it a Condition, that the Captain should give a written renunciation of all further claim upon the Captors. This he declined,
in consequence of which, the Nanina was condemned as prize of War, by a vice-admiralty Court, and sold for a song. An appeal from the sentence of Condemnation was prosecuted and is now pending before the High Court of Appeals. Having been instructed by the Secretary of State, to support the claims of the proprietors of the Nanina, ministerially I addressed on the 10th. of June last a Note to Lord Castlereagh in their behalf, which he answered on the 27th. of that Month, by a refusal to interfere in the case, referring to the rigorous right of War, and to the refusal of the Captain to take back his vessel, without reserving a further claim for costs and damages— A copy of my Note and of Lord Castlereagh’s answer, were sent last Summer to Mr. Murray; but from his Letter to Smith it is very doubtful whether he has received it, for he still urges most earnestly that I should apply to the British Government, and supposes it impossible that they should shut their eyes to the justice of his claim. Mr Walker now came to ask my advice, upon a proposal made by the Captors to relinquish to the owners of the Nanina the net proceeds of the sale, and have the cause dismissed from the Court— He said if it was pushed on to trial the Condemnation must be confirmed— He supposed the proposal made by the Captors was to save themselves the expences of the Appeal, which would absorb all the proceeds, or leave a mere trifle not worth being distributed among them— Mr Walker and his house thought nothing better for the owners could be done than to accept the proposal; but the amount of the proceeds will not exceed £400 Sterling, and Mr Murray’s claim being for upwards of £6000. they had thought it necessary to ask my advice before they concluded what to do. I told him I thought it best to save from the wreck what they could. That by the positive refusal of this Government to interfere, for the owners, they were left at the mercy of the captors, and I believed nothing better could be done or expected than to accept their proposal. He said the house thought so too; and Coll: Palmer, a member of Parliament, had offered to present the case to the attention of the House of Commons, which might still be done, though he did not expect to any good purpose— Mr Joy came next, and Mr Walker left the Office— General Boyd with Mr Storer, and Mr Rotch, with Mr Maurice Birkbeck successively followed. I enquired of General Boyd if he knew where Coll. M’Rae, and Major Thayer were, at present— He thought in France— Mr Birkbeck is a very intelligent English farmer; and has published a tour in France which he made in the Summer of 1814. But he has the project of removing with his family to settle in the United States. The account that he gives of the state of the Country is as dark and gloomy as those which come in all other directions. He says that notwithstanding the great increase in the price of grain and flour since last Winter the agricultural state of the kingdom is worse than it was then. But he admits that the appretiation of Bank-Notes to be of equal value with gold and silver is unaccountable to him; and contrary to all his prognostications— And his explanations, how in the midst of all the cries of distress the Revenue continues to be nearly as productive as ever are not quite satisfactory— These visitors detained us at the Office, until past five, and it was half past seven when we got home— There was a packet of National Intelligencers from 16 to 28 November, received last Night from Liverpool— Bed between nine and ten.

Day. The latter half of this Month I have usually risen by Candle-light; but with great irregularity between four and nearly nine O’Clock, forming an average of half past six: the morning has been constantly employed upon the Index to my Journal, and since that was completed, to the Journal itself. The hours between Breakfast and dinner, from 11. A.M. to 6. P.M. have been given as usual to writing Letters, reading Newspapers and walking for exercise.— Since Ellen Nicholas left us, there has been no Evening Music— I usually pass the Evening however from dinner time with my family, sometimes idly and sometimes reading. Three or four times I have spent it, writing in my cabinet. The time of retiring for the Night has been about half an hour earlier since I have risen earlier in the Morning.

The review of the year while it brings again motives of boundless gratitude to the supreme Being, presents a period of more constant occupation, and as little or less good effect than any other equal portion of my life. It has been incessantly busy, and totally lost. At the renewal of the year, I bless the divine goodness for the Preservation of my Parents and family; praying for a continuance of the same mercies, and for the will and the power faithfully to discharge all my duties hereafter.
